Question 1.Question: The delineation of constituencies is a major duty of the
Question 1.Explanation: The function of the electoral commission is to conduct elections, demarcate constituencies, compile and update voters' register and announce election results.

Question 2.Question: To qualify for absorption into the administrative cadre of the civil service in Nigeria, an applicant must be
Question 2.Explanation: The administrative cadre is the highest level of staff in the civil service. To qualify for the posts in the administrative cadre, one has to have university education and obtain a degree, which must be backed up with years of experience.

Question 3.Question: The principle of check and balances reinforces separation of powers in order to
Question 3.Explanation: Checks and balances enable each organ of government to keep the others from abusing their powers and it also ensures that each organ of government hold others accountable in the making of good decisions.

Total votes in an election
An area's involvement in politics

Question 4.Question: Proportional representation is a system of allocating seats in the legislature based on
Question 4.Explanation: Proportional representation is usually used to elect legislative representatives in multi-member constituencies, in which each political party gets seats in proportion to the percentage of votes cast in favour of such political party.

Legislators have t proceed on a recess

Question 5.Question: Delegated legislation becomes unavoidable when
Question 5.Explanation: Delegated legislation is advantageous because it reduces the workload of the legislature, enables experts to legislate on technical matters, saves time and cost for the legislation and allows for quick response.

Ideology

Question 6.Question: A major issue that distinguishes pressure groups from political parties is
Question 6.Explanation: Pressure groups differ from political parties in so many ways. Pressure groups aim to influence the government while political parties aim to acquire political power; pressure groups are made up of people with similar values, beliefs and status while political parties are made up of people with same political ideology.

Full political rights

Social rights only

Question 7.Question: Citizenship in a modern state expresses the status of a person who possesses
Question 7.Explanation: A citizen in a person, whom under the constitution and the laws of a particular state is a member of the political community. He owes allegiance to the country and is entitled to the enjoyment of some fundamental rights.

Question 8.Question: The structure of the civil service is based on
Question 8.Explanation: The civil service is structured according to various criteria into successive ranks. The administration staff consists of the highest ranking staff of the civil service. Next is the executive staff, the professional staff, clerical staff and auxiliary staff in their order of importance.

Options.Value: Executive order
Executive review

Question 9.Question: In a presidential system of government, the president checks the legislature through
Question 9.Explanation: The veto power of the president is exercised through his assent to bills. After a bill has been passed by the legislative, it is sent to the president for assent. However, if the president feels that the bill is unfavorable on any ground, he can withhold his assent.

Question 10.Question: The economic basis of feudalism is
Question 10.Explanation: Feudalism is a form of government based on the ownership of land. Agriculture is the main occupation due to the importance associated with land. The lords are land owners while serfs are made to work on the land as servants.

Capitalism

Question 11.Question: The creation of a classless society is the ultimate aim of
Question 11.Explanation: Communism is a political and economic growth in which the society is based on the common possession of the means of production and the equal distribution of goods, lands and resources.

Question 12.Question: One of the sources of a constitution is
Question 12.Explanation: The source of a constitution are written documents, organic laws (also known as statutory law), judicial decisions, principle of philosophers, constitutional customs and conventions and lastly, experience of the people.

Question 13.Question: The fundamental assumption on which the idea of the rule of law is based is
Question 13.Explanation: The most important element of the rule of law is supremacy of the constitution. It is only when the supremacy of the fundamental law of the land is recognized and respected that the rule of law can flourish in a country.

Question 14.Question: The principle of separation of powers was made popular by
Question 14.Explanation: The principle of separation of powers was propounded by John Locke but it was made popular and modernized through the writings of Baron de Montesquieu.

Question 15.Question: Delegated legislation refers to the laws made by
Question 15.Explanation: Delegated legislations are laws made by administrative authorities, public authorities or agencies. These are not legislative but executive bodies.

Question 16.Question: A written constitution is distinguished by its
Question 16.Explanation: A written constitution is one which is codified or written down in a single document unlike the unwritten one which is scattered across several documents.

Question 17.Question: One of the greatest advocates of socialism was
Question 17.Explanation: Karl Marx was an advocate of socialism; Baron de Montesquieu advocated separation of powers; A.V. Dicey advocated Rule of law; while Adam Smith advocated division of labour.

Question 18.Question: The form of government in which the powers of the hereditary ruler are limited is
Question 18.Explanation: In a constitutional monarchy, the power of the ruler is limited by the constitution. He or she is supposed to rule in line with the laws of the country because his/her powers are not absolute.

Question 19.Question: In a dominant one-party system, there is
Question 19.Explanation: In a one party or single party, there is only one legal and legitimate political party. It enjoys unchallenged authority and it keeps being elected year over year, for a long period of time.

Question 20.Question: Individual as opposed to collective responsibility is a basic feature of the
Question 20.Explanation: In a presidential system of government, each minster is responsible for his portfolio. His appointment and dismissal does not affect any other minister in governance.

Question 21.Question: A bill could become law without the president's assent if
Question 21.Explanation: After a bill has passed through the houses, is sent to the president for assent, and he refuses to assent the bill, the legislature can pass the bill into law if it is supported by a vote of two-third majority of the legislature.

Question 22.Question: In a federal system, the essence of specifying the constitutional relationship between the centre and the constituent units is to
Question 22.Explanation: In a federal system, the constitution provides for the sharing of powers among the tiers of government. This will enable each tier to know its functions and limitations.

Question 23.Question: A crucial requirement for the successful conduct of elections is
Question 23.Explanation: One of the requirements for the conduct of a free and fair election is an independent electoral body. Once an electoral body receives bribes, is discriminatory or bias due to influence from the executive, legislature, judiciary or private citizens, the conduct of a free and fair election will not see the light of day.

Question 24.Explanation: Fascism originated from Italy during the World War 1. Fascist leaders were Benito Mussolini of Italy, Adolf Hitler of Germany and Engelbert Dollfub of Austria.

Question 25.Question: In the monarchical system of government, sovereignty is vested in the
Question 25.Explanation: A monarchical system of government is one in which a King or Queen rules. In this system of government, sovereignty belongs to the royals. A good example is Saudi Arabia.

Question 26.Question: One merit of a written constitution is its
Question 26.Explanation: A written constitution is rigid, thereby making it difficult to be used indiscriminately by despotic rulers. It cannot be changed easily to suit the whims and caprices of a dictator or a few people. Its amendment process requires the contribution of the legislature as well as the citizens of the state.

Question 27.Question: A human community that is usually cohesive and homogenous is a
Question 27.Explanation: A nation is a homogenous group of people who form a distinct community by inhabiting a definite territory. The people of a nation have a common or related blood, a common language, religion, history, tradition, customs and behavior.

Question 28.Explanation: The executive sometimes perform the legislative function of law – making through delegated legislation. Delegated legislations are laws made by administrative authorities, local government and ministerial bodies, which are all part of the executive arm of government.

Question 30.Explanation: A foreign policy is characterized by stability, foresight, engagements and visionary decisions that will bring more efficiency and investments nationally and internationally.

Question 31.Question: Nigeria hosted the Commonwealth Conference which eventually led to the independence of
Question 31.Explanation: The January 1966 Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference was the fifteenth meeting of the Heads of Government of the Commonwealth of Nations. It was the first such meeting to be held outside of the United Kingdom, being held in Lagos, Nigeria, and was hosted by the country's Prime Minister, Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa. The sole purpose of the meeting was to discuss the white minority rule regime in the British colony of Rhodesia and the means by which multi-racial rule could be achieved.

Question 32.Explanation: Multilateral relations are formed due to the quest of three or more countries coming together to solve the same problem, address the same issue or achieve a common goal.

Question 33.Question: The major factor militating against the efficient operation of electoral commission in Nigeria is
Question 33.Explanation: The electoral commission in Nigeria suffers from political interference. They are usually not independent as they are influenced by politicians, private individuals and parties while carrying out their duties.

Options.Value: Training and promotion of public servants
Settlement of disputes among individuals
Addressing the grievances of individuals and groups

Question 34.Question: The major objective of the Public Complaint Commission is
Question 34.Explanation: The Public Complaint Commission, also known as the Ombudsman, is a body which receives and examines complaint of mal-administration, injustice, corruption and inefficiency of public and private officials in the course of their duties. Training and promotion of public servants is the duty of the Public Service Commission while ICPC and EFCC are in charge of fighting corruption and fiscal indiscipline.

Question 35.Question: The three registered political parties at the inception of Nigeria's Fourth Republic were
Question 35.Explanation:
PDP, AD and APP

The three parties which contested the 1999 general elections at the inception of the fourth republic in 1999 were People's Democratic Party (PDP), All People's party (APP) and Alliance for Democracy (AD).

Question 36.Question: The Sharia legal system was first introduced in the Fourth Republic
Question 36.Explanation: In January 2000, Zamfara State adopted Sharia law and Kano followed suit in June 2000. Other states that have adopted the Sharia Penal Code are Sokoto, Kastina, Bauchi, Borno, Jigawa, Kebbi and Yobe state.

Question 37.Question: Quota system and federal character principles were entrenched in the 1979 constitution to ensure
Question 37.Explanation: In the 1979 constitution, federal character ensured that appointment of qualified personnel into federal agencies or as minister was done to include representation of every part of the country, so that there wouldn't be segmentation. The quota system on the other hand, enabled the allocation of revenue to different states to be in line with size, population mineral availability, etc.

Question 38.Question: Workers in public corporations are known as
Question 38.Explanation: Public servants are workers in government or public cooperations which provide essential utilities for the people. Workers in government ministries are called Civil Servants while private employees are people who work in private business enterprises. Workers in all the organisations mentioned, who have received special training in specified disciplines are called professional employees.

Question 39.Explanation: The objectives of privatization include efficiency of enterprises; raising of funds for financial socio-economic developments and creation of more jobs.

Question 40.Explanation: It was promulgated on May 24, 1966 by then Head of State, Major General Thomas Aguiyi Ironsi. It was called the Unification Decree which changed Nigeria from a federation to a unitary state.

Question 41.Question: Nigeria broke diplomatic relations with France in 1961 because of
Question 41.Explanation: France conducted its first nuclear bomb test at Reganne, Algeria, in the Sahara desert. The breaking of ties with France because of this act was a demonstration of Nigeria's adoption of Africa as centre piece of her foreign policy since independence in 1960.

Question 50.Explanation: The Commonwealth of Nations is a voluntary association of 53 independent and sovereign states. Most are former British colonies and colonies of other countries have also joined over the years.
